But how did it all begin, what does Parliament
do all day and how do you fit in?

18.20.text:
Parliament has evolved throughout its long
history to become what it is today, changing

22.77.text: over time to meet the needs of the people.

25.92.text: Two key historical events began this process.

28.81.text:
In 1215, King John put his seal on Magna Carta
and agreed to a list of 63 rules set out by

35.84.text:
a group of barons. This ensured for the first
time that no-one, not even the king, was above the law.

43.59.text:
Fifty years later, Simon de Montfort, for
the first time, invited representatives of

48.04.text: the towns and shires to his 1265 parliament.

51.86.text:
These events established the foundations for
the representative democracy we have today

56.32.text:
and from this point onwards the power to make
decisions for the nation passed, over time,

Let’s take a closer look at the UK Parliament
today…

71.44.text:
Parliament is made up of three parts – the
House of Commons, the House of Lords, and

77.16.text:
The House of Commons is the elected chamber
of Parliament. It debates big issues, proposes

82.17.text:
laws, amends existing ones, and challenges
the Government’s work.

86.60.text:
There are 650 Members of Parliament, or MPs,
who each represent a constituency in the UK.

93.07.text:
They belong to either a political party or
are independent, and are elected by constituents

98.17.text: of the area they want to represent.

100.82.text:
The leader of the party that has the most
MPs elected after a general election becomes

104.99.text: the Prime Minister and heads up the Government.

107.10.text:
They choose a cabinet made up of 20 senior
ministers who coordinate each Government department’s

114.23.text:
Parties not in power are called the opposition.
MPs from the opposition and government question

119.80.text:
the Government on policy and proposed
laws. The speaker keeps the house in order

126.57.text:
The House of Lords is the second chamber and
shares the making and shaping of laws with

130.73.text:
the House of Commons. It has around 800 members
and it’s made up mostly of life peers, and

136.64.text: also includes hereditary peers and bishops.

139.99.text:
Lords are selected for their knowledge and
experience, and hold Government to account

143.76.text:
by using their expertise to look at laws and
issues in detail.

147.71.text:
The monarch’s role is mainly ceremonial.
They meet the Prime Minister once a week to

151.79.text:
hear what’s going on in Parliament and formally
agree every new law.

155.57.text:
But that’s not all! There are also people
working behind the scenes who support the

160.35.text:
work of Parliament; clerks, librarians,
researchers and many more.

167.14.text:
The Government has been elected to run the
country, and Parliament holds the Government

173.23.text: to account for us, the public… but how?!

176.64.text:
Prime Minister’s Questions and Ministerial
Questions give MPs and Lords the opportunity

180.85.text:
to challenge the Government’s policies.
It’s in these debates that they can share

184.92.text:
the views of their constituents and the public
and how new policies may affect them.

189.97.text:
Another important way Parliament can scrutinise,
look in detail, at the work of Government

They are made up of either MPs, Lords or a

subject and make recommendations on improvements.

209.89.text:
Witnesses with expertise in the area under
scrutiny are called to give evidence, which

216.82.text:
Members of the public, like you, with a view
on the subject can also give evidence for

Both Houses in Parliament share responsibility
for making and shaping laws. But where do

240.25.text:
A Bill is a proposal for a new law, or to
change an existing law, and comes from lots

245.61.text:
of places, like governing and opposition parties,

252.36.text: So how does an idea get turned into a law?

255.61.text:
Imagine the Government wanted to place greater
controls over the internet.

259.29.text:
A proposal called a Green Paper is published,
which presents the Government’s ideas for

263.54.text:
future policy. This is open for public discussion
with interested groups like internet service

268.90.text:
providers and others likely to be affected.
Once findings are gathered a white paper is

273.99.text:
published which outlines a firmer plan for
Government policy.

278.29.text:
Cabinet Ministers must agree whether the proposal
is taken forward. Once agreed a Bill is drawn

283.74.text:
up and the Minister responsible for the policy
introduces the Bill to Parliament for debate.

288.74.text:
MPs and members of the House of Lords comment
on, debate or amend the Bill through several

294.39.text:
stages, and at the end of the process, apart
from very rare circumstances, it must be agreed

300.40.text:
It is then passed to the monarch who gives
formal approval, or Royal Assent, and the

305.18.text: Bill becomes law, called an Act of Parliament.

General elections take place in the UK usually

Before elections, candidates need to campaign

Parties standing for election publish a declaration

One way to have a say in how the country is
run is to use your vote.

You have to be 18 or over to vote in General

407.66.text:
There are lots of other ways to get involved

You can visit an MP in their local constituency
office, or you can even travel to the Houses

425.37.text:
Lords have knowledge and experience in specific

Sometimes though there’s strength in numbers,

If you’re passionate about an issue you

453.95.text:

These groups use different methods to get

And don’t forget, you can get your voice
heard in school or college too by joining

(or starting!) a student council – a bit
